awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Envimetric - Soil and water contamination predictive modeling tools
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovative Research (SBIR) Phase II project is a significant reduction in the cost and time to remove hazardous contaminants from the soils and groundwater impacting communities. 

Properties observed from thousands of contaminated sites serve as inputs to a computerized mathematical model of the site, forecasting the most likely shape and depth of a contaminant plume. This machine learning model gives remediation planners access to a fast delineation of volume to be remediated as well as the uncertainty of the modeled estimate. This saves time and money searching for these contaminants that are deep underground and in groundwater. This Phase II project will expand on the Phase I prototype, creating an operational product capable of reaching the needs of environmental engineers and scientists around the globe, providing the stimulus to cut remediation time and cost in half.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:  The Phase II SBIR award to Azimuth1, LLC resulted in the formation of a new capability to produce scientifically based estimates of hazardous material plume locations in soil and groundwater. Azimuth1 was awarded a patent entitled "Forecasting soil and groundwater contaminat migration" in Feb 2023.  Azimuth1 colleagues presented at four technical conferences, and published two articles related to Envimetric methods and practice.  Azimuth1 also hosted a free educational webinar on the practice of AI/ML in the environmental sciences and engineering fields.

Broader impacts:  The software as a service model Azimuth1 used to deploy the EnviMetric model supports users in enginering, real estate, and environmental consulting.  These users apply the EnviMetric method to contaminated spill sites all across the US and abroad, fulfilling the vision of faster, safer, and less costly clean up of hazardous materials that endanger drinking water and environments where people live and work.

During the course of the SBIR program, Azimuth1 employed environmental analysts, data scientists, and software developers.  Additonally the company established an internship program for University students in environmental science and related degree programs.  This program called GroundTruth, trained and employed students during breaks, holidays, summers, off hours, and other times they were otherwise available.  This program provided the students with flexible work opportunities related to their professional field of study, and provided Azimuth1 with a steady flow of new data to train and improve the AI/ML models in EnviMetric.
